description: From Ancient Greek ἐν- (en-, “in”) + θάλπω (thálpō, “to warm”). Coined by Dutch physicist Heike Kamerlingh Onnes, but first used in print by J. P. Dalton in 1909 in a paper titled "Researches on the Joule-Kelvin-effect, especially at low temperatures".

entries.meaning: (physics, chemistry) In thermodynamics, a measure of the heat content of a chemical or physical system.
examples:
H
        =
        U
        +
        p
        V
      
    
    {\displaystyle H=U+pV}
  
, where H is enthalpy, U is internal energy, p is pressure, and V is volume.
